verses.text: In the second year of the reign of Nebuchadnezzar, Nebuchadnezzar had dreams. His spirit was troubled and his sleep left him.
verses.comment: Like Pharaoh in Genesis, the king's troubled dream sets the stage for God's revelation. The narrative establishes God's sovereignty over rulers.

verses.text: Then the king commanded that the magicians, the enchanters, the sorcerers, and the Chaldeans be summoned to interpret the king’s dreams. So they came in and stood before the king.
verses.comment: The futility of pagan wisdom is highlighted, as only God gives true insight. The Chaldeans were the priestly caste in Babylon.

verses.text: And the king said to them, 'I have dreamed a dream, and my spirit is troubled to know the dream.'
verses.comment: Dreams are often a means through which God communicates his will, both here and in the New Testament (Matt. 2:12).

verses.text: Then the Chaldeans spoke to the king in Aramaic, 'O king, live forever! Tell your servants the dream, and we will show the interpretation.'
verses.comment: From this point, the text switches to Aramaic until Dan. 7:28. Aramaic was the common diplomatic language.

verses.text: The king answered the Chaldeans, 'The word from me is firm: if you do not make known to me the dream and its interpretation, you shall be torn limb from limb, and your houses shall be made a ruin.'
verses.comment: Nebuchadnezzar’s demand shows his suspicion and the severity of absolute monarchy. Acts as a test for true divine wisdom.

verses.text: But if you show me the dream and its interpretation, you shall receive gifts, rewards, and great honor from me. Therefore, show me the dream and its interpretation.
verses.comment: Worldly rulers reward what they consider supernatural wisdom. God grants true wisdom to his faithful (cf. James 1:5).

verses.text: They answered again and said, 'Let the king tell his servants the dream, and we will show the interpretation.'
verses.comment: The wise men try to maintain an appearance of ability while relying on human methods, lacking real access to divine mystery.

verses.text: The king answered, 'I know with certainty that you are trying to gain time, because you see that the word from me is firm.'
verses.comment: Nebuchadnezzar’s insistence exposes the emptiness of the magicians’ claims apart from God. Points to the need for authentic revelation.

verses.text: If you do not make the dream known to me, there is but one sentence for you. You have agreed together to speak lying and corrupt words before me till the times change. Therefore, tell me the dream, and I shall know that you can show me its interpretation.
verses.comment: The king perceives their limits. Only God reveals the hidden and the future (cf. 1 Cor. 4:5).

verses.text: The Chaldeans answered the king, 'There is not a man on earth who can reveal what the king demands, for no king, lord, or ruler has ever asked such a thing of any magician, enchanter, or Chaldean.'
verses.comment: Their admission prepares us for God to act. Points to the infinite gap between human and divine wisdom.

verses.text: 'The thing that the king asks is difficult, and no one can reveal it to the king except the gods, whose dwelling is not with flesh.'
verses.comment: This prepares for the idea of the divine dwelling among men—fulfilled when the Word became flesh in Christ.

verses.text: Because of this the king was angry and very furious, and commanded that all the wise men of Babylon be destroyed.
verses.comment: A death sentence for false wisdom. Like Herod later (Matt. 2:16), insecurity breeds violence.

verses.text: So the decree was issued that the wise men were to be killed, and they sought Daniel and his companions, to kill them.
verses.comment: Daniel and his friends are lumped in with the pagan wise men, showing the high stakes of their witness.

verses.text: Then Daniel replied with prudence and discretion to Arioch, the captain of the king’s guard, who had gone out to kill the wise men of Babylon.
verses.comment: Daniel's wisdom in action parallels the prudence of saints who trust God while using human means wisely.

verses.text: He answered and said to Arioch, the king’s captain, 'Why is the decree of the king so urgent?' Then Arioch made the matter known to Daniel.
verses.comment: Daniel seeks understanding before acting—a hallmark of spiritual maturity.

verses.text: And Daniel went in and requested of the king that he would give him time, that he might show the king the interpretation.
verses.comment: Daniel’s request shows faith that God answers prayer and reveals hidden things.

verses.text: Then Daniel went to his house and made the matter known to Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah, his companions,
verses.comment: Prayer in community is a pattern for the Church’s intercession (cf. Acts 1:14).

verses.text: and told them to seek mercy from the God of heaven concerning this mystery, so that Daniel and his companions might not perish with the rest of the wise men of Babylon.
verses.comment: God’s mercy is sought through united prayer. Mystery (Aramaic: raz) points forward to the New Testament use of 'mystery' (Col. 1:26-27).

verses.text: Then the mystery was revealed to Daniel in a vision of the night. Then Daniel blessed the God of heaven.
verses.comment: God freely reveals secrets to his servants—shadowing God’s to-be-completed revelation in history.

verses.text: Daniel answered and said: 'Blessed be the name of God forever and ever, to whom belong wisdom and might.'
verses.comment: Praise always precedes or follows true revelation. Daniel's hymn foreshadows liturgical prayers in the faith.

verses.text: He changes times and seasons; he removes kings and sets up kings; he gives wisdom to the wise and knowledge to those who have understanding.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty isn’t limited to spiritual matters but includes earthly kingdoms (Rom. 13:1).

verses.text: He reveals deep and hidden things; he knows what is in the darkness, and the light dwells with him.
verses.comment: God’s light dispels all darkness, pointing to Christ as the true light (John 1:9).

verses.text: To you, O God of my fathers, I give thanks and praise, for you have given me wisdom and might, and have now made known to me what we asked of you, for you have made known to us the king’s matter.
verses.comment: Daniel acknowledges that all gifts and victories come from God alone. Prayer and thanksgiving are integral.

verses.text: Therefore Daniel went in to Arioch, whom the king had appointed to destroy the wise men of Babylon. He went and said thus to him, 'Do not destroy the wise men of Babylon; bring me in before the king, and I will show the king the interpretation.'
verses.comment: Daniel’s plea saves others—a type of Christ’s saving mediation.

verses.text: Then Arioch quickly brought Daniel before the king and spoke thus to him, 'I have found among the exiles from Judah a man who will make known to the king the interpretation.'
verses.comment: Even in exile, God’s people act as a blessing to the nations (cf. Gen. 12:2-3).

verses.text: The king said to Daniel, whose name was Belteshazzar, 'Are you able to make known to me the dream that I have seen and its interpretation?'
verses.comment: Human wisdom alone is not sufficient; Daniel’s humility will set up credit to God.

verses.text: Daniel answered the king and said, 'No wise men, enchanters, magicians, or astrologers can show to the king the mystery that the king has asked.'
verses.comment: Daniel distinguishes the true God alone as the source of wisdom.

verses.text: But there is a God in heaven who reveals mysteries, and he has made known to King Nebuchadnezzar what will be in the latter days. Your dream and the visions of your head as you lay in bed are these:
verses.comment: ‘Latter days’ points to ultimate fulfillment in God’s plan—a key motif for prophetic understanding.

verses.text: To you, O king, as you lay in bed came thoughts of what would be after this, and he who reveals mysteries made known to you what is to be.
verses.comment: God is Lord of history and the future, granting insight as he wills.

verses.text: But as for me, this mystery has been revealed to me, not because of any wisdom that I have more than all the living, but so that the interpretation may be made known to the king, and that you may know the thoughts of your mind.
verses.comment: Daniel’s humility highlights all revelation as God’s gift. Servants called to humility precede apostolic leaders.

verses.text: You, O king, were watching, and behold, a great image. This image, mighty and exceedingly bright, stood before you, and its appearance was terrifying.
verses.comment: The image represents earthly kingdoms. God often uses dreams and visions for prophetic revelation.

verses.text: The head of this image was of fine gold, its chest and arms of silver, its middle and thighs of bronze,
verses.comment: Successive metals represent successive kingdoms. The head of gold is Babylon.

verses.text: its legs of iron, its feet partially of iron and partially of clay.
verses.comment: Iron symbolizes strength, clay weakness or division. The composite feet anticipate instability in human empires.

verses.text: As you looked, a stone was cut out by no human hand, and it struck the image on its feet of iron and clay and broke them in pieces.
verses.comment: The stone, not made by human hands, is a clear reference to God’s kingdom—fulfilled in Christ, the cornerstone.

verses.text: Then the iron, the clay, the bronze, the silver, and the gold were all crushed together, and became like chaff from the summer threshing floors; and the wind carried them away so that not a trace of them could be found. But the stone that struck the image became a great mountain and filled the whole earth.
verses.comment: God’s kingdom is enduring and universal, contrasting with unstable earthly kingdoms—echoing Christ’s Church on earth with a visible unity.

verses.text: This was the dream. Now we will tell the king its interpretation.
verses.comment: Daniel shifts to interpretation—connecting vision to application.

verses.text: You, O king, the king of kings, to whom the God of heaven has given the kingdom, the power, the might, and the glory,
verses.comment: All power comes from God, ultimately made manifest in Christ, 'King of Kings.'

verses.text: and into whose hand he has given, wherever they dwell, the children of man, the beasts of the field and the birds of the heavens, making you rule over them all—you are the head of gold.
verses.comment: Echoes Adam’s dominion; human kingdoms are allowed by God but are fleeting.

verses.text: After you shall arise another kingdom inferior to you, and another third kingdom of bronze, which shall rule over all the earth.
verses.comment: A succession of world empires is prophesied, showing history’s purpose directed by God.

verses.text: And there shall be a fourth kingdom, strong as iron, for iron breaks and shatters all things. And like iron that crushes, it shall break and crush all these.
verses.comment: The fourth kingdom is traditionally seen as the Roman Empire, a backdrop for Christ’s coming.

verses.text: And as you saw the feet and toes, partly of potter's clay and partly of iron, it shall be a divided kingdom, but some of the strength of iron shall be in it, as you saw the iron mixed with soft clay.
verses.comment: A divided kingdom is vulnerable, unlike the true, undivided kingdom established by God through his Church.

verses.text: And as the toes of the feet were partly iron and partly clay, so the kingdom shall be partly strong and partly brittle.
verses.comment: Historically fulfilled in divided Rome, this also points to all later temporal powers.

verses.text: And as you saw the iron mixed with soft clay, so they will mix with one another in marriage, but they will not hold together, just as iron does not mix with clay.
verses.comment: Intermarriage among royal houses brings only apparent unity; God’s people look for a deeper unity in truth and Spirit.

verses.text: And in the days of those kings the God of heaven will set up a kingdom that shall never be destroyed, nor shall the kingdom be left to another people. It shall break in pieces all these kingdoms and bring them to an end, and it shall stand forever.
verses.comment: The everlasting kingdom refers to Christ's kingdom—founded not by force, but by the Spirit through unity and apostolic succession.

verses.text: Just as you saw that a stone was cut from a mountain by no human hand, and that it broke in pieces the iron, the bronze, the clay, the silver, and the gold, the great God has made known to the king what will come to pass after this. The dream is certain, and its interpretation is sure.
verses.comment: The stone not cut by hands symbolizes God's work initiated from heaven—fulfilled in Christ (1 Peter 2:4-8).

verses.text: Then King Nebuchadnezzar fell on his face and paid homage to Daniel, and commanded that an offering and incense be offered up to him.
verses.comment: The king's reverence shows the impact of God’s truth. Daniel, as a prophet, mediates God's presence among the nations.

verses.text: The king answered Daniel and said, 'Truly, your God is God of gods and Lord of kings, and a revealer of mysteries, for you have been able to reveal this mystery.'
verses.comment: Nebuchadnezzar acknowledges the Most High; revelation of divine mysteries always requires faith and obedience.

verses.text: Then the king gave Daniel high honors and many great gifts, and made him ruler over the whole province of Babylon and chief prefect over all the wise men of Babylon.
verses.comment: Daniel stands as a model for faithful leadership in the world, reminiscent of Joseph in Egypt (Gen. 41:40-41).

verses.text: Daniel made a request to the king, and he appointed Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego over the affairs of the province of Babylon. But Daniel remained at the king’s court.
verses.comment: All four men are honored and remain faithful amid pagan culture. Their unity and prayer foreshadow the leadership and faithfulness of the apostles in the Church.
